content: The "POWER Act" aims to address high rates of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking by providing pro bono legal services. Efforts are needed at all levels to combat this violence and support victims. According to the National Network to End Domestic Violence, over 10,000 requests for services, including legal representation, were not met in a single day in September 2014. Pro bono assistance can provide legal representation, emergency shelter, transportation, and childcare to victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Research shows that legal assistance reduces the likelihood of future violence and helps survivors move forward by increasing the chances of obtaining a protective order. Pro bono legal assistance can help victims of domestic violence obtain protective orders, with a higher success rate for those represented by an attorney. Judges should encourage lawyers to provide pro bono resources to help victims escape the cycle of abuse and raise awareness of domestic violence issues. A dedicated army of pro bono attorneys will raise awareness of domestic violence issues and empower survivors through legal assistance events organized by district courts. District courts will organize public events promoting pro bono legal services to empower survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking, especially focusing on Indian or Alaska Native victims. Each chief judge has the discretion to design and implement these events. Each chief judge has the discretion to organize public events promoting pro bono legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. They must maximize local impact and access to services. Reporting requirements mandate submitting event details annually to the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts and a compilation to Congress. The Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts must compile and summarize reports on public events promoting legal services for survivors of violence. The reports should include an analysis of how each event aligns with the Act's goals and suggestions for improvement. The funding for these requirements will come from existing funds.
